Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X03-BDK1-DYTY-C0J2-00000-00US regulators snip away at Google as the scrutiny grows;Technology Intelligence Democrats and Republicans alike switch attention to tech giant, Hannah Boland, Natasha Bernal and James Titcomb report2019-09-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:24ZLexisNexisBUSINESS;NEWSPg. 4US regulators snip away at Google as the scrutiny growsTechnology Intelligence Democrats and Republicans alike switch attention to tech giant, Hannah Boland, Natasha Bernal and James Titcomb report

Fines and investigations have become a part of everyday life for Google. Hot on the heels of a $170m (£139m) settlement, agreed with US regulators yesterday over claims it had been breaching children's privacy law with its YouTube site, the search giant looks set to face yet another investigation.

This time, though, it can expect more than a rap on the knuckles. The inquiry, expected to be launched next week by more than half of the US's state attorney generals, would mark a significant coordinated action to rein in the internet giant - and could very well be Google's toughest hurdle yet.

It is a move that has been a long time coming. For years, American antitrust bodies have been seen to be dragging their heels, their last major attempt to curb Google's market power in 2013 resulting in them opting against imposing hefty penalties.

Recently, though, the mood has changed. Within the last month, a new bill has been introduced in the US which, if signed into law, would hand regulators more powers to stop monopolies forming, including fines of up to 15pc of their US revenues.

Presidential candidates, meanwhile, have been vocal in their ambitions to break up Big Tech, most notably Democrat front-runner Elizabeth Warren who warned the companies have "too much power - too much power over our economy, our society, and our democracy". Ms Warren has said that under her presidency, Google would not be allowed to promote its own services, for example its job adverts function, within search results. And in July, the US Department of Justice launched its own antitrust investigation into big tech companies, saying their dominance had "stifled innovation".

One might expect that the raging trade war between the US and China might help to sweep aside competition concerns in favour of a pro-business agenda.

But for now, it is unlikely that Sundar Pichai, Google chief executive will find a sympathetic ear in the Oval Office. Donald Trump's impassioned defence of US business has seemingly not extended to Google. Last month, he tweeted that Pichai was in the Oval Office, "working very hard to explain how much he liked me, what a great job the Administration is doing, that Google was not involved with China's military, that they didn't help Crooked Hillary over me in the 2016 Election".

Historically, giant multinationals haven't had too much to fear from the US. The European Commission has launched probe after probe, and imposed ever-escalating fines against Google that have totalled (EURO)8.2bn (£7.4bn), but little has been done to rein in home-grown US companies, viewed as the epitome of capitalist success.

"In the US there is more inclination to believe that most of these practices may have pro-competitive effects," says Aitor Ortiz, an antitrust analyst at Bloomberg Intelligence.

"Europe, on the other hand, takes a stronger approach, they're more interventionist."

But, that isn't to say America has never taken a hard line against monopolies. Perhaps the best known example of this is the break-up of Standard Oil in 1911, in which the Government invoked a rarely used act to loosen the company's hold over as much as 95pc of America's oil production. More recently that same law, the Sherman Act, was used in the early Eighties to break up telephone service giant AT&T and its Bell Labs into so-called "Baby Bells", and was cited in the US Department of Justice's case against Microsoft - a company which was ultimately not split up after a settlement was reached.

Any investigation into Google would also rely on the Sherman Act, and proving that the search giant has both "monopoly power and exclusionary conduct" says Sally Hubbard, now part of the Open Markets Institute, and the former assistant attorney general for New York State.

What it would be likely to entail is the state attorney generals "investigating first" and looking "inside the brain of the company" she says. Then, once all the information is on the table, something that would "probably take a couple of years", federal regulators would get involved, bringing with them further-reaching powers.

But, still, question marks remain over a number of aspects of any inquiry. For one thing, what would it be specifically looking at? After all, the Republican states may be more concerned about Google's role in political censorship, but the Democrats are all-together more interested more in its concentrated power.

One early investor says the political divide could actually be bad news for Google, because even if politicians cannot agree on what the problem is, there does seem to be a bipartisan belief that the company is simply too big. The remedy for that might be blunter than that for other problems, potentially the company being banned from further acquisitions, or even a break-up.

But, Ortiz says a break-up wouldn't be easy. "All the companies in the Google ecosystem, you can't really take part of it and make it profitable by itself. You can't sell, say, Google Search by itself."

In fact, what experts see as much more likely to happen is for "farreaching remedies" to be introduced, similar to those seen in Europe during the Nineties during the liberalisation of the telecoms market, providing more access to the networks to open up competition.

"I would think with Google it would be more about saying things like you would have to provide access to your data, or to the index system that you have," Ortiz says.

Google has strongly denied that its power is thwarting innovation or hurting businesses. "We have created new competition in many sectors, and new competitive pressures often lead to concerns from rivals. We have consistently shown how our business is designed and operated to benefit our customers," Adam Cohen, its director of economic policy, told a US hearing in July.

And since most of its products are free to consumers, it is less straightforward to prove that consumers have been harmed than with other famous antitrust cases.

One thing is certain. Google is likely to face a whole flurry of new investigations, and potentially fines over the coming years, not just in America, but also from regulators around the globe.

But experts say fines alone might be unlikely to change the company's behaviour. Alphabet, Google's parent company, had $121bn in cash at the end of June, and since it has paid multibillion dollar penalties to the EU in each of the last three years, it may now simply see it as the cost of doing business.

Some are hopeful that any antitrust action will not just affect Google's purse strings. "I hope it will be beyond fines," says Hubbard. After all, "their business practices need to be changed, and their incentives need to change."

'Europe takes a stronger approach, more interventionist than the United States'

'Business practices need to be changed, and their incentives need to change'

$121bn The amount Alphabet, Google's parent company had in cash at the end of June this year

<xhtml:span id="h2" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... BUSINESS Pg. 16 US <xhtml:span class="hit">regulator</xhtml:span> targets Facebook Brent Kendall, John D. McKinnon, Ryan Tracy The US ...</xhtml:span>

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60VN-WJK1-JD3N-5426-00000-00US regulator targets Facebook2020-09-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:24ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 16US regulator targets FacebookBrent Kendall, John D. McKinnon, Ryan Tracy

The US Federal Trade Commission is gearing up to file a possible antitrust lawsuit against Facebook by the year-end, according to sources, in a case that would challenge the company's dominant position in social media.

The case preparations come after the FTC has spent more than a year investigating concerns that Facebook has been using its powerful market position to stifle competition, part of a broader -effort by US antitrust authorities to examine the conduct of a handful of dominant tech companies.

No final decision has been made on whether to sue Facebook, sources say, and the commission doesn't always bring cases even when it is making preparations to do so, such as when it decided against filing an antitrust complaint against Google in 2013 after a lengthy investigation.

Facebook is still in the process of making its case to the commission, even as the probe has been progressing into its late stages, and recent efforts by FTC staff have included taking testimony from CEO Mark Zuckerberg, something the commission didn't do during a prior probe of the company's privacy practices. That matter resulted in a record-breaking $US5bn settlement.

A majority on the five-member FTC would need to vote in favour of any lawsuit. The commission comprises three Republicans, including chairman Joseph Simons, and two Democrats.

Details of the FTC's likely legal theories in any Facebook lawsuit could not be learned. The company last year disclosed it was under investigation by the FTC, and The Wall Street Journal has previously reported that one focus of the agency's probe is the company's past acquisitions of potential competitors.

FTC staff members are continuing to ask questions about past acquisitions, as well as about -issues related to how Facebook manages its platform with regard to app developers.

The company has argued that its acquisitions aren't anticompetitive and have improved products and experiences for its users.

Facebook hasn't yet held discussions with the FTC's commissioners, which would probably happen at the very final stage of the process.

If Facebook were to lose an antitrust case, the FTC could seek a range of remedies designed to promote competition against the company, from restrictions on how Facebook operates to breaking off pieces of its business. The commission can't unilaterally dictate such changes; it would first have to prove in legal proceedings that the company violated federal antitrust law, and that such changes were necessary.

Asked about Facebook in an August 5 hearing before the Senate Commerce Committee, Mr -Simons said he could not discuss specific companies. "We have the ability to look back at consummated mergers and to undo them," he said, adding that the agency had also asked major tech platform companies for information about past acquisitions that were not required to be reported to antitrust authorities.

Facebook already has moved to integrate different services it has acquired, which it says it is doing to improve consumers' experience, for instance by allowing them to message one another through different Facebook-owned apps.

A case against the social-media giant would open up a second big front in the government's pursuit of Big Tech. The Justice Department, which shares antitrust authority with the FTC, is planning to file an antitrust lawsuit soon against Alphabet's Google, The Wall Street Journal has reported.

A case against either company would probably take years to resolve, meaning the officials who bring a lawsuit may not be around to see its conclusion. The November 3 presidential election could affect the -future of any case, though Republicans and Democrats have been critical of tech-company practices, including at Facebook and Google.

The FTC previously has blessed Facebook's expansion through acquisitions of companies, including photo-sharing app Instagram in 2012, though not without qualms. Some on the commission worried about the implications of that deal, but weren't sure they could win a case, the Journal has reported.

The FTC allowed Facebook's purchase of messaging service WhatsApp in 2014. The company had acquired scores of firms over the past decade.

Facebook has vigorously defended its deals, saying apps such as Instagram have grown in popularity because Facebook has used its resources to make them better.

Mr Zuckerberg, testifying in July before a House antitrust subcommittee, called the Instagram acquisition "an amazing success story", noting Facebook "invested heavily in building up the infrastructure and promoting it and working on security and working on a lot of things around this".

House Judiciary Committee chairman Jerrold Nadler, a Democrat, called the Instagram deal "exactly the type of anticompetitive acquisition that the antitrust laws were designed to prevent. This should never have happened in the first place." Politicians also raised questions about whether Facebook exploits outsized market share when it interacts with app developers or moderates online speech.

The antitrust subcommittee, which obtained more than a million documents from top tech companies, is expected to release a report in the coming weeks detailing its findings regarding -potentially anticompetitive behaviour in the tech sector and whether a legislative response is needed. The Wall Street Journal

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VHS-B3J1-JC5R-24B6-00000-00US regulator to monitor big tech2019-02-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:24ZLexisNexisUS regulator to monitor big tech

THE U.S. Federal Trade Commission (FTC), under pressure to keep closer tabs on big tech companies such as Alphabet’s Google and Facebook, said Tuesday it would create a task force to monitor the sector and investigate anticompetitive conduct.



The FTC’s Bureau of Competition will put some 17 staff attorneys on the task force, which will consult on tech-related merger reviews, investigations and reviews of consummated tech deals.

“It makes sense for us to closely examine technology markets to ensure consumers benefit from free and fair competition,” FTC Chairman Joe Simons said in a statement.

The agency’s Bruce Hoffman, head of the Bureau of Competition, did not rule out taking action to undo a consummated deal if anticompetitive behavior was found, but declined to discuss specific transactions.

Unwinding a deal after it has closed is “very rare,” said Henry Su of the law firm Constantine Cannon LLP.

Facebook, already under investigation by the FTC, is accused of violating a 2011 consent decree regarding privacy by allowing the personal information of 87 million users to end up in the hands of Cambridge Analytica, a Britain-based political consulting firm hired by President Donald Trump’s 2016 U.S. election campaign.

Advocacy groups have urged the FTC to require Facebook to unwind its purchases of Instagram, used to share photos, and WhatsApp, a private messaging app.

The App Association, which represents app makers, said it looked forward to the task force’s work.

The Retail Industry Leaders Association, which represents brick and mortar stores whose businesses have been disrupted by online retailers, said creation of the task force will “bring needed scrutiny to the relatively few technology platforms that control a growing share of modern commerce.” (SD-Agencies)

urn:contentItem:5WCN-K731-JCBW-N3H5-00000-00US REGULATOR TO PROBE YOUTUBE ON CHILD PRIVACY;IN BRIEF2019-06-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:24ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3US REGULATOR TO PROBE YOUTUBE ON CHILD PRIVACYIN BRIEF

The US Federal Trade Commission is said to be in the advanced stages of an investigation into Youtube's handling of videos aimed at children. The probe, which could result in fines against Google-owned Youtube, followed complaints by parents and consumer groups that the firm had collected data of young users, according to media reports last night. The groups also complained Youtube had allowed harmful and adult content to appear in searches for children's content. The move follows increased scrutiny on big tech firms from US regulators such as Google, as voices such as presidential hopeful Elizabeth Warren calling for the breakup of the largest firms. Separately, Google survived a proposal to break up its hold on the market at its shareholder meeting last night.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y62-RGC1-DY93-M0Y0-00000-00US regulator to review Big Tech acquisitions over past decade2020-02-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:24ZLexisNexisUS regulator to review Big Tech acquisitions over past decadeWashington, Feb 11 2020

A US regulatory agency said Tuesday it would look into acquisitions made by five Big Tech firms over the past decade -- opening the door for potential antitrust reviews.

The bombshell announcement by the US Federal Trade Commission opens the door to possible investigations of deals made by Amazon, Apple, Facebook, Microsoft and Google parent Alphabet since 2010.

The FTC said in a statement it ordered the five firms "to provide information about prior acquisitions not reported to the antitrust agencies" between January 1, 2010 and December 31, 2019.

The move comes amid growing scrutiny of tech platforms which have dominated key economic sectors, and calls by some activists and politicians to break up the Silicon Valley giants.

Antitrust experts have debated the legal and practical issues of attempting to "unwind" past acquisitions.

The FTC, one of the regulatory agencies that conducts antitrust reviews, said it would examine whether some of the deals "might have raised competitive concerns."

"This initiative will enable the Commission to take a closer look at acquisitions in this important sector, and also to evaluate whether the federal agencies are getting adequate notice of transactions that might harm competition," said FTC chairman Joe Simons.

The US Justice Department has already said it is reviewing potential anticompetitive actions by major tech platforms, and attorneys general from the majority of US states have launched antitrust investigations of Google and Facebook.

The actions come against a growing "techlash" reflecting declining public trust in big online firms, and fines levied against Facebook and Google over privacy violations.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XR6-2KD1-DYWP-R1CC-00000-00US regulator weighs action against Facebook over how its apps interact - report2019-12-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:24ZLexisNexisBUSINESSUS regulator weighs action against Facebook over how its apps interact - report

REUTERS: The U.S. Federal Trade Commission is considering seeking a preliminary injunction against Facebook Inc over concerns that how its apps interact could violate antitrust law, The Wall Street Journal reported https://www.wsj.com/articles/ftc-weighs-seeking-injunction-against-facebook-over-how-its-apps-interact-11576178055?mod=searchresults&page=1&pos=1 on Thursday, citing people familiar with the matter. Facebook shares closed 2.7per cent lower, reflecting fears the potential regulatory move could be a first step toward forcing the company to sell apps WhatsApp and Instagram, its fast-growing acquisitions.

If the FTC proceeds, it would likely ask a court to bar Facebook from enforcing policies regarding how the world's largest social network's apps work with each other and potential rivals, the newspaper reported. The FTC may also ask a court to forbid Facebook from moving ahead with plans to more fully integrate subsidiaries that it has purchased, the newspaper said. Apart from antitrust concerns, Facebook and other tech giants are facing criticism over privacy lapses, how they handle vast quantities of consumer data, and accusations of bias in the polarized U.S. political environment. The Wall Street Journal said the FTC could file for the injunction as early as next month. Facebook and the FTC declined to comment. Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg announced plans in March to integrate Facebook's messaging services as part of a proposed shift toward more private forms of social networking. Under the proposal, users of Facebook units Messenger, WhatsApp and the direct messaging system within Instagram will be able to communicate with each other, and end-to-end encryption will be extended across the three services. Zuckerberg's strategy reflects the importance of Instagram and WhatsApp as Facebook's flagship app struggles to attract new young users in the company's most lucrative markets. Instagram ads drive much of Facebook's revenue growth, while the company is slowly moving toward making money from WhatsApp, which has surged to a user base of 1.5 billion people since its US$22 billion acquisition in 2014. The properties are already integrated to some degree, with users able to link their accounts and advertisers able to use one system to place ads across different platforms. Encrypting messaging systems will restrict Facebook's ability to see the content of users' messages, but the company has not divulged whether the integration plan may deepen other types of data sharing between the units. Facebook, Alphabet Inc's Google, Amazon.com Inc and Apple Inc all face antitrust investigations by the Justice Department and House of Representatives Judiciary Committee. The FTC was also known to be investigating Facebook while groups of state attorneys general are looking at Facebook and Google. U.S. Attorney General William Barr said on Tuesday he hoped to have Justice Department investigations of the big tech platforms completed next year. Barr said the Justice Department review was not limited to antitrust, but that looking for anti-competitive behavior was "front and center." (Reporting by Ayanti Bera in Bengaluru and Diane Bartz in Washington; Editing by Shailesh Kuber, Leslie Adler and Richard Chang) - Reuters

urn:contentItem:5XR6-2KD1-DYWP-R1CD-00000-00US regulator weighs action against Facebook over how its apps interact -report2019-12-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:24ZLexisNexisBUSINESSUS regulator weighs action against Facebook over how its apps interact -report

REUTERS: The U.S. Federal Trade Commission is considering asking a court to stop Facebook Inc from moving ahead with plans to integrate its WhatsApp, Instagram and Messenger subsidiaries, The Wall Street Journal reported on Thursday, citing people familiar with the matter. Facebook shares closed 2.7per cent lower, reflecting fears the potential regulatory move could be a first step toward forcing the company to sell apps WhatsApp and Instagram, its fast-growing acquisitions. Facebook has plans to allow users of its units Messenger, WhatsApp and the direct messaging system within Instagram to communicate with each other, and end-to-end encryption will be extended across the three services.

A source familiar with the matter said the FTC has not asked Facebook to halt the integration, a step that would normally precede a legal challenge. The Wall Street Journal said the FTC could file for an injunction to halt the integration as early as January. Apart from antitrust concerns, Facebook and other tech giants are facing criticism over privacy lapses, how they handle vast quantities of consumer data, and accusations of bias in the polarized U.S. political environment. Facebook and the FTC declined to comment. Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg announced plans in March to integrate Facebook's messaging services as part of a proposed shift toward more private forms of social networking. Zuckerberg's integration strategy reflects the importance of Instagram and WhatsApp as Facebook's flagship app struggles to attract new young users in the company's most lucrative markets. Instagram ads drive much of Facebook's revenue growth, while the company is slowly moving toward making money from WhatsApp, which has surged to a user base of 1.5 billion people since its US$22 billion acquisition in 2014. The properties are already integrated to some degree, with users able to link their accounts and advertisers able to use one system to place ads across different platforms. Encrypting messaging systems will restrict Facebook's ability to see the content of users' messages, but the company has not divulged whether the integration plan may deepen other types of data sharing between the units. Facebook, Alphabet Inc's Google, Amazon.com Inc and Apple Inc all face antitrust investigations by the Justice Department and House of Representatives Judiciary Committee. The FTC was also known to be investigating Facebook while groups of state attorneys general are looking at Facebook and Google. U.S. Attorney General William Barr said on Tuesday he hoped to have Justice Department investigations of the big tech platforms completed next year. Barr said the Justice Department review was not limited to antitrust, but that looking for anti-competitive behavior was "front and center." (Reporting by Ayanti Bera in Bengaluru, Katie Paul in California and Diane Bartz in Washington; Editing by Shailesh Kuber, Leslie Adler and Richard Chang) - Reuters

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WTD-4N31-DY2T-F46R-00000-00U.S. regulator willing to break up Big Tech firms; FTC chair eyes undoing past mergers2019-08-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:24ZLexisNexisFINANCIAL POSTPg. FP10U.S. regulator willing to break up Big Tech firms; FTC chair eyes undoing past mergersDavid MclaughlinBloombergWASHINGTON

The head of the U.S. Federal Trade Commission said he's prepared to break up major technology platforms if necessary by undoing their past mergers as his agency investigates whether firms including Facebook Inc. are harming competition.

FTC chair Joe Simons, who is leading a broad review of the technology sector, said Tuesday that breaking up a company is challenging, but could be the right remedy to rein in dominant companies and restore competition.

"If you have to, you do it," Simons said about breaking up tech companies. "It's not ideal because it's very messy. But if you have to, you have to."

Simons is overseeing a tech task force to examine conduct in the industry and could move to unwind mergers if investigators find the deals were anticompetitive. The agency has opened a broad investigation into Facebook, including whether it acquired startups to thwart competition, according to people familiar with the matter. Facebook bought photo-sharing site Instagram in 2012 and WhatsApp, a messaging service, in 2014. The FTC approved both acquisitions at the time. Critics including Facebook co-founder Chris Hughes have called for antitrust enforcers to unwind those deals. U.S. antitrust enforcers could move to unwind the acquisitions even though they previously won approval, Simons said. The FTC could say "we made a mistake," he said. He would need a court to approve such a move. Facebook declined to comment.

Giant tech firms are coming under increasing scrutiny in Washington over a wave of acquisitions of startups. Antitrust experts and lawmakers argue the deals have allowed the companies to shut down competition by buying - and eliminating - emerging rivals.

Presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren, a Massachusetts senator, has been among the most outspoken about acquisitions by big tech companies, saying earlier this year they are "using mergers to limit competition" by buying competitors. She cited Facebook's deal for Instagram, Google's acquisition of mapping company Waze and Amazon. com Inc.'s takeover of Diapers.com.

Simons didn't confirm details of the Facebook probe beyond what the company disclosed in July, when it said that the FTC had initiated a broad probe into several business lines - social media, digital advertising and mobile applications. Any inquiry into its past acquisitions would focus on what would have happened to those firms if they hadn't been bought by Facebook, Simons said.

"There's a question about what caused Instagram to be as successful as it is," Simons said. "Was it the fact that the seed was already there and it was going to be germinated no matter what or was the seed germinated because Facebook acquired it?" !@COPYRIGHT=© 2019 Postmedia Network Inc. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XYV-3S41-JDVW-N0R0-00000-00US regulatory pressures to shape big tech's 2020 spending strategies2020-01-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:24ZLexisNexisDATA DISPATCHExclusiveUS regulatory pressures to shape big tech's 2020 spending strategiesAnna Akins, Stefen Joshua Rasay

With big M&A likely off the table, some industry observers expect U.S. tech firms to use their cash to get ahead of looming regulatory penalties and also to bolster their respective businesses in growth areas such as 5G and cloud computing.

As 2020 kicks off, cash-rich technology companies face pressure to put their deep capital reserves to work, but heightened regulatory and political scrutiny could limit companies' options, analysts said.

Microsoft Corp., Alphabet Inc. and Apple Inc. each reported hundreds of billions of dollars in liquid assets in 2019, including cash and cash equivalents, short-term investments and other securities. While investors typically encourage companies with large liquid holdings to pursue mergers and acquisitions, analysts note the growing unrest on Capitol Hill toward big tech including antitrust investigations and calls to break up the companies will likely make major M&A activity unfeasible. Instead, they see cash being allocated toward other areas, including next-generation 5G mobility service, cloud computing and regulatory compliance.

"The prospect for very large deals I think is not there, especially in this environment," said Samantha McLemore, portfolio manager at Miller Value Partners, an investment management company.

McLemore instead urged tech companies to be much more aggressive this year in returning capital to shareholders through stock repurchases and dividends, saying this presents a "huge opportunity" to spend down their hefty cash piles.

Another option, according to Daniel Morgan, a senior portfolio manager at financial service firm Synovus, is for U.S. tech firms to use their cash to get ahead of looming regulatory penalties and also bolster their respective businesses. This is especially true for Facebook Inc., he said.

"Probably No. 1 [for Facebook in 2020] will be concerns about the regulatory front," Morgan said in an interview.

Facebook was already hit with a record-breaking $5 billion fine by the U.S. Federal Trade Commission in 2019 related to the company's user data practices. Moreover, the company is the subject of an open antitrust probe from the FTC, and the agency is also reportedly contemplating pursuing a preliminary injunction against Facebook over competition concerns related to its practices for integrating apps like WhatsApp Inc. and Instagram LLC.

Facebook, Morgan said, will likely put money aside for potential fines that may result from the ongoing investigations into the company.

As of the third quarter 2019, Facebook reported holding $52.27 billion in liquid assets.

Facebook is hardly the only U.S. tech giant expected to face regulatory pressure in the coming year. State regulators are engaged in antitrust investigations of both Alphabet's Google LLC and Facebook, while federal antitrust regulators at the U.S. Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission are also engaged in broader probes evaluating how large tech platforms may have harmed consumers. And ahead of the 2020 U.S. presidential election, candidates such as Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts have advocated for breaking up Facebook, Amazon.com Inc. and Google.

With all of this regulatory scrutiny making further M&A unlikely in the near term, these companies must determine how to spend their cash most effectively in 2020.

Morgan predicted Microsoft and Alphabet will continue building out their cloud computing businesses to better compete with Amazon, which remains a leader in the cloud market.

Both Microsoft and Alphabet have plenty of dry powder to spend. Microsoft ended the September 2019 quarter with $136.61 billion in liquid assets, up from $133.83 billion in the June 2019 quarter. Alphabet followed with $121.18 billion.

Morgan expects Oracle Corp., which has largely avoided the regulatory spotlight compared to peers, to focus its efforts on dividends and share buybacks this year. Oracle Corp. ended the September quarter with $35.70 billion in liquid assets.

As for Apple, which ended the September quarter with $100.56 billion in liquid assets, the company is expected to jump into the next-generation 5G wireless arena by designing a "robust" platform to facilitate faster download speeds and other advancements promised by the new technology, said Timothy Lesko, partner and portfolio manager at Granite Investment Advisors, an investment advisory firm.

"Apple needs to provide a robust platform for software developers to develop really compelling 5G experiences on iPhone, iPad, TV, all those places," Lesko said in an interview. "That requires a lot of spending on the platform and probably the server and cloud space for those developers to host that 5G data."

Apple, which was noticeably missing from the 5G race last year, is expected to release a 5G iPhone at its hardware refresh event this fall.

Wedbush Securities analyst Daniel Ives said the regulatory backlash on big tech remains a "lingering worry" that will cause "near-term uncertainty" for Wall Street investors this year.

"Regulation on [big tech] will be the 'political football' kicked around in the Beltway with a number of paths this situation may take, especially heading into a presidential election year," he said.

Debates' potential market impact; Market gains: FB, Google & Amazon on pace for worst month ever; WSJ: Devon Energy, WPX in talks to merge; Investigating the Investigators; Maria's sources: Durham RPT won't be come before Nov 3; Flynn documents released: probe into flawed application for wiretapping; RPT: Contractor throws away Trump mail- in ballots; Project Veritas finds ballot harvesting by Omar allies.Maria Bartiromo, Cheryl Casone

JAIME COLBY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: I'm Jaime Colby. Thanks so much for watching Strange Inheritance and remember you can't take it with you.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. Happy Monday everyone. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Monday September 28. Your top stories right now 6 AM on the button on the east coast.

Breaking news, no John Durham interim report before the election. It is unlikely we will see any indictments before the November 3 election as well but sources tell me the criminal investigation is expanding.

We'll talk about how far the scope extends this morning. Then who knew what and when. We've got bombshell new documents this morning related to the unlawful surveillance of a former Trump advisor. This as former FBI director Jim Comey testifies this upcoming Wednesday and from the Senate Judiciary Committee and former FBI attorney Andrew McCabe is slated for October 6 on entrapping General Michael Flynn.

The lawyer for General Michael Flynn Sidney Powell this morning live at 8 a.m. Eastern. Markets this morning are showing a firmer tone. Take a look at where we stand with futures. We're looking at a rally under way here with the Dow futures up 257 points right now, almost 1 percent.

The NASDAQ up 132 and the S&P 500 higher by 30 points. Wednesday marks the final trading day of the month and the third quarter. We've a look back and look ahead. Friday saw a day of green largely boosted by technology stock rally that pushed the NASDAQ into positive territory for the week.

Friday, the Dow industrials up 358 points. NASDAQ up 240 and the S&P higher by 52. 36 days to go now. The 2020 election is just over a month away. Both candidates are preparing for the first debate of the season, Tuesday night. We will preview.

White House Press Secretary Kayleigh McEnany is here with the latest. Plus President Trump's pick for the Supreme Court and its impact. Amazon Prime day revealed. The new date on when you can score the best deals to kick off your holiday shopping season and then keeping it real.

Gwyneth Paltrow's Instagram birthday post is turning heads and making a buzz this morning. Mornings with Maria is live right now.

Global markets this morning are having a firmer tone. Take a look at European indices here. The FT100 is up 73. The CAC40 is up 82 and the Dax index higher by 305 points, that's 2.5 percent boosted by investor optimism in the banking sector.

Banks higher this morning. Asian markets mostly higher overnight as well despite new sanctions by the United States against Chinese chipmakers. Shanghai composite was down a fraction. Best performer Korea, KOSPI index up 1.25 percent.

Now some of the top stories that we're watching this morning. We're just one day away from the first presidential debate. The 90 minute debate in Cleveland hosted by Fox news channel's Chris Wallace will have President Trump and Joe Biden facing off over a flow of issues including the Supreme Court pick, the economy and the integrity of the election.

President Trump issuing a challenge to the former vice president ahead of the faceoff.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I'm willing to take a drug test. He should too because he's had a very uneven - I watched him with some of the - when he was debating Pocahontas and Harris who treated him so badly but I watched him and he was out of it, right? And then I watched him against Bernie Sanders and he was OK.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The Biden campaign issuing this response. "Vice President Biden intends to deliver his debate answers in words. If the president thinks his best case is made in urine, he can have at it.

Joe Biden taking a break from the campaign trail today. Meanwhile President Trump will give an update on the coronavirus this afternoon. Confirmation hearings for President Trump's Supreme Court nominee Amy coney Barrett, will begin October 12.

This as Minority leader Chuck Schumer says he will not meet with Judge Barrett at all.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D-NY): I believe first that the whole process has been illegitimate and second, because she's already stated that she is for overturning the ACA.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Fellow New York senator Kirsten Gillibrand along with Senators Mazie Hirono and Richard Blumenthal also said they will not meet with Judge Barrett. They accused her of wanting to overturn Obamacare and Roe V. Wade.

The number of deaths due to coronavirus meanwhile approaching 1 million worldwide. This as Wisconsin, Minnesota, Oregon and Utah, all report record single day infections. The country passed 7 million cases since the pandemic arrived. Meanwhile some states are moving forward with reopening plans.

New York starting limited indoor dining on Wednesday and Florida announcing that starting Friday, there will be no longer any restrictions on restaurants, bars and nightclub capacity. A federal judge hits pause on the Trump administration's ban on downloading TikTok. The ruling coming just hours before it was supposed to take effect.

The Chinese owned app says it is pleased with the decision after arguing a ban would violate the First Amendment. President Trump has called the app, a national security risk. TikTok is still finalizing a deal to sell its U.S. operations to software giant Oracle and retail giant Walmart.

Futures this morning a rally. We have a pretty good firmer tone underway this morning. We're looking at a 300 points gain right at the gate as investors await key economic data this week including personal income, consumer spending and the all-important September jobs report.

Of course it's also the beginning of the fourth quarter on Thursday. Joining this morning is Yardeni Research president Ed Yardeni. Also joining the conversation all morning long is Payne Capital Management President Ryan Payne and Pollster and the President of maslansky + partners, Lee Carter.

Great to see everybody this morning. Thank you for being here. Ed Yardeni, let's kick it off with you. What's your take in terms of this rally under way this morning and what do you believe drives markets going into the fourth quarter?

ED YARDENI, PRESIDENT, YARDENI RESEARCH: Well, I think we've just been in a classic correction. The market had a melt up since March 23 as a result of all the easy money provided by the Fed and on top of that, we had a very big fiscal stimulus package.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I think that's great. Finally, socially distant trick or treating. One Texas couple decided that coronavirus would not stop them from celebrating Halloween, their favorite holiday. They created a candy cannon to make sure kids get their candy while also keeping their distance and a candy robot. Lee, this is a creative way to save Halloween.

CARTER: I love it. I love it. I know the kids this year are all struggling to figure out how to get some sense of normalcy and necessity is the mother of invention. And I think this is going to be awesome to see how people are going to do this, great for the couple. I hope this is a wild success and I'd love to see how more people are going to be able to make sure that our kids are out there having a great time on Halloween this year.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's the thing. I mean, people know that there's no trick or treating now. They've got to adapt to the coronavirus. That's what we're doing, Ryan. We keep adapting.

PAYNE: Exactly right, exactly right. Necessity is the mother of invention. I'm all about the candy cannon. I want to get involved somehow, Maria, that just sounds awesome.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: All right, still ahead, the word on Wall Street, it's coming up. Hear what top final analysts are saying and now about your money, helping you watch your wallet, it all starts next hour. MORNINGS WITH MARIA is live on Fox Business, we'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Monday morning everybody, thanks so much for joining us, I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Monday, September 28th. Your top stories right now just before 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WTW-T0J1-JBJN-M1WF-00000-00U.S. says it could "break" tech companies if that improves competition: what it means2019-08-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:24ZLexisNexisU.S. says it could "break" tech companies if that improves competition: what it means


The United States is prepared to "break" major technology companies if necessary, said Joe Simons, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission (FCC), as part of a series of regulatory investigations into anti-competitive practices in the sector.


In an interview published on The Bloomberg website on Tuesday night, Simons argued that a path to bring competitiveness back to the technology sector may be to undo mergers that companies have made in the past.
The FTC recently opened an investigation into Facebook and investigates whether the company acquired other rival companies to eliminate competition.
"If necessary, you do," Simons said of a company's division, adding, "It's not ideal because it's very messy. But if you have to, you do it," he said.
Antitrust experts cited by Bloomberg argue that big tech firms have used a wave of new company acquisitions to eliminate emerging rivals.
Facebook, for example, bought Instagram in 2012 and WhatsApp in 2014, acquisitions that were once approved by the FTC.
"Here's a question about what caused Instagram to be as successful as it is," Simons said, and continued, "Was it the fact that the seed was already there and that it was going to germinate no matter what or the seed germinated because Facebook acquired it?"
Simons argued today that he has heard President Donald Trump's complaints about the size and political leanings of major technology platforms, but assured that he will not let that affect his decisions.
Trump has repeatedly attacked internet companies and their CEOs through his Twitter account, and has accused them of silencing conservative opinions.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XMR-V7P1-DY19-C15V-00000-00'US's best' CEO wants Google and Facebook regulated and bitcoin banned2019-12-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:24ZLexisNexis'US's best' CEO wants Google and Facebook regulated and bitcoin bannedPaul Smith

VMware CEO Pat Gelsinger has piloted the company through buyouts, the cloud boom and a feud with Microsoft, he says big tech must now become a force for good.

The chief executive of US business technology giant VMware has urged lawmakers to take simple, but tough steps to regulate the misinformation spread on Facebook and Google, saying "bad apples" are spoiling the reputations of all technology companies and the industry must strive to be seen as a force of societal good.

VMware boss Pat Gelsinger was named as America's best CEO in an annual survey by employment website Glassdoor earlier this year where bosses are ranked by employees, but he told The Australian Financial Review he is frustrated at a pervasive broad brush impression that the tech sector has gone bad.

In Australia for his company's vFORUM event in Sydney, Mr Gelsinger said public concerns about poor data privacy practices at tech giants and the spread of misinformation online should be addressed by legislation, and that he believed Australia has a huge opportunity to be a regional tech leader.

Mr Gelsinger spoke to the Financial Review after a keynote conference address, in which he had shared the stage with ASX's deputy CEO Peter Hiom to talk up the world-leading blockchain project VMware is supporting at the stock exchange, and also in which he had described Bitcoin as "bad for the world."

"When I make that statement I cite two characteristics. One is the technology itself is engineered to consume extraordinary amounts of power ... and then estimates say that well over 95 per cent of the financial value traded in Bitcoin is for criminal purposes," Mr Gelsinger said.

"If you listen to Peter from the ASX then they talk about "digital ledger technology," because they don't want to say 'blockchain' and get associated with all the bitcoin stuff ... but the underlying technology holds extraordinary promise and value."

Mr Gelsinger's popularity among employees - evidenced by the Glassdoor award - comes down largely to the fact that he has steered his company through severely choppy waters in recent years, and seen it emerge as a key player in the booming cloud computing ecosystem.

His concerns about the negative perception of the tech sector and the actions of some of its biggest players, comes from outside the immediate areas where VMware conducts business, and relate to the idea of technologies being morally neutral, but frequently used in nefarious ways.

"I am frustrated because I see there is one paintbrush saying 'tech is bad,' because there are some bad apples, and those things disappoint me. I think there should be regulation and more data privacy, and GDPR is a great place to start," Mr Gelsinger said.

"Then I think Facebook and Google are content providers and should be regulated like content providers, it's not that hard. If somebody says something slanderous on the evening news tonight, there is libel and court mechanisms ... it's not that hard to just take the mechanisms that have been well established already and make them appropriate.

"If people are bringing more and more of their social lives, their personal narratives and their medical lives online, then they should be protected and that's part of the role of governments and regulation."

Survival and revival

VMware burst on to the tech scene 20 years ago and became a pioneer in virtualisation technology, which allows companies to run multiple virtual versions of their machines on a single server.

However its growth stalled due to its huge market share, it was acquired by EMC and it faced questions about its long term future as recently as a year ago when its current majority shareholder Dell (it owns over 80 per cent of VMware stock) went public again.

Mr Gelsinger has diversified the company into the cyber security sector through a recent $US2.1 billion acquisition of Carbon Black, as well as signing major and lucrative cloud computing alliances with Amazon Web Services and long term VMware rival Microsoft.

Asked why he thinks his personal stock has risen so markedly in the CEO rankings, he cited a strong internal company culture, the basic fact that the company is performing well financially and the relief his staff feel at the company's re-emergence into a "second act"

"We needed to shift our strategy as we got to 80 per cent market share and it was saturated and flattening ... also when Dell and EMC merged our stock dropped in half and there were rumours floating around that VMware would be crushed and that I would be fired, then after all this tumult Dell goes public," Mr Gelsinger said.

"After all this stuff we've gotten to a point where we're sailing well, the wind is in the sails, we feel the momentum of the industry and we're not fighting through these turbulent waters where people are saying we're going to be capsized by cloud."

He describes his relationship with tech industry legend and VMware chairman Michael Dell as "interdependent but also independent."

While Dell is a majority shareholder, VMware has alliances with HP and Lenovo, which both compete with Dell in hardware, and also with IBM and AWS, which both go up against Dell's cloud-related business.

Mr Gelsinger said Mr Dell's longstanding good relations with Microsoft helped VMware ink a long-awaited partnership between the companies earlier this year, whereby VMware is available via Microsoft's Azure cloud service.

Despite Mr Gelzinger and Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella having been well-known to each other personally and professionally for over 25 years, the two companies had remained as unfriendly foes since VMware's inception.

"When Satya and I stood on stage at Dell Tech World, we had Michael the peacemaker and me and Satya on stage, it almost felt like a Middle East peace conference coming together," he said.

Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella joins Dell CEO Michael Dell and VMware CEO Pat Gelsinger to talk about VMware Cloud infrastructure on Azure - further expanding their partnership #DellTechnologiesWorld   @DellEMCZA   pic.twitter.com/1xM1HSDAvn

??? Aki Anastasiou (@AkiAnastasiou) April 29, 2019

"I thought 'hey we've fought with these guys for two decades, but customers want us to work together, so, let's go figure it out.'

"It wasn't easy after two decades of spitting, scratching and clawing at each other, people show up in the same room it's like, I'm not sure what the Aussie comparison is, but in the US, we call it the Hatfields and McCoys we don't like each other 'just because' ... but it is going well."

Looking forward, Mr Gelsinger said he has high hopes for VMware's attempts to crack open the cyber security sector, which he describes as "broken," based on the fact that more money is spent on it each year, while ever more breaches occur.

However he said his observations on work at the ASX leads him to believe Australia can push for a regional advantage in leading the next generation of financial technology based on the blockchain.

While he dislikes Bitcoin, Mr Gelsinger said blockchain technology could dramatically cut the cost of viably providing bank accounts, meaning big regional opportunities exist for establishing operations in multiple countries across Asia.

"We're going to keep working on doing better ??? less energy consumption, more efficiency, more scalability, faster resolution so that people can use the technology more, and as the ASX has said, this idea of being able to have automated technology to build and deliver immutable consensus, is applicable to lots of problems," he said.

"Maybe it becomes a vehicle for Australia, if we get this working right, Maybe you become a bigger trading partner for all of ASEAN ... Maybe it becomes a core underlayment of larger interbank transfers and the basis for currency.

"Then as transactional fees get dramatically reduced you look at being able to do banking in third world countries where they don't have access to banking services ... Now people can bank and save who never had that opportunity before, so you start changing economies."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60XT-6XP1-DY4H-K2MC-00000-00US searches for a solution to Google's dominance2020-09-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:24ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:1US searches for a solution to Google's dominanceDanny Fortson, San Francisco

An impending competition case by the Department of Justice signals a new phase in Washington's war on Big Tech

The Department of Justice will file a landmark antitrust suit against Google as early as this week, kicking off a new phase in Washington's increasingly aggressive attacks on Big Tech.

Alphabet, Google's parent, runs the world's most popular video service, YouTube. It has the dominant search engine, the world's biggest web browser (Chrome), the most popular mobile operating system (Android), and the top mapping operation.

However, the DoJ's suit - the biggest against a tech company since it filed an anti-monopoly case against Microsoft in 1998 - is likely to focus on Google's dominance of search, and the ads that it powers.

The case is part of a sweeping crackdown on tech giants, including Apple and Facebook, which rivals and regulators claim use their immense power to tilt the market in their favour, suffocate competitors, distort society and limit free speech.

In addition to the impending action, William Barr, the US attorney general, last week sent a draft law to Congress that would shrink an immunity shield that frees social media giants such as Facebook and YouTube of liability for content posted by users. That legal protection, known as Section 230, is shaping up to be a key battleground for Donald Trump's administration, which claims the tech behemoths censor conservative voices.

A group of Republican senators has called for a vote this week on whether to subpoena the bosses of Alphabet, Facebook and Twitter for a hearing on Section 230. Trump met Republican state attorneys general to discuss the issue.

The pressure is coming from customers and rivals as well. Barry Diller, the billionaire head of IAC, a tech holding firm that includes Expedia and dating app Match, last week dubbed Google an "absolute monopoly". He told The Washington Post that Expedia spent up to $5bn (£3.9bn) a year on ads with Google, but since the search giant started to build its travel business, Expedia's ads received less prominent placement.

"Google is essentially competing with our services while taking our money," Diller said. "I've said to most senior leaders at Google, 'We all are serfs in your universe, in your land. But it's wise to treat your serfs well, which I think you are increasingly not doing. Because if you let that go on for too long, the serfs tend to rise up and attack in hordes.' "

Google has denied any wrongdoing, claiming its products, which are offered free, benefit consumers and support innovation. But Diller's critique is at the heart of the government's case against Google, and is what legal experts say is a vulnerability also for Apple.

Both companies are gatekeepers through which others must pass to reach billions of customers. Google, for example, handles 90% of all internet searches. The App Store and Google's Play store are the new shop windows. Apple estimated that in 2019, the App Store facilitated more than $500bn in sales.

To operate these marketplaces, the tech giants charge vast sums. However, they also sell their own products through them, and set up the rules to favour their own. Apple's App Store is ground zero. A group of tech firms last week announced the formation of a lobbying organisation, the Coalition for App Fairness. It includes the likes of Spotify, Diller's Match Group, and Epic Games, the maker of popular video game

Fortnite

that last month sued Apple over its App Store rules.

The group claims the 30% cut Apple takes on any purchase made through the store is unfair, not least because its own services, such as Spotify rival Apple Music or Arcade - a competitor to Epic - are not subject to the fee.

Diller said Apple's 30% tax was "egregious" , calling it a "hostage payment."

Apple brings in an estimated $15bn a year from App Store fees and rules the marketplace with an iron fist, kicking out any developer that falls foul of the rules, such as requiring that all transactions go through Apple's payment system.

Google also takes 30%, and is expected to update its Android guidelines this week to make it harder for companies to avoid paying it. It also agreed last week to pay $310m to settle a lawsuit over how it handled sexual misconduct claims against former executives.

urn:contentItem:60XV-1NV1-DYTY-C1JR-00000-00US searches for a solution to Google's dominance;An impending competition case by the Department of Justice signals a new phase in Washington's war on Big Tech2020-09-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:24ZLexisNexisBUSINESS AND MONEY;NEWSPg. 7US searches for a solution to Google's dominanceAn impending competition case by the Department of Justice signals a new phase in Washington's war on Big Tech

The Department of Justice will file a landmark antitrust suit against Google as early as this week, kicking off a new phase in Washington's increasingly aggressive attacks on Big Tech.

Alphabet, Google's parent, runs the world's most popular video service, YouTube. It has the dominant search engine, the world's biggest web browser (Chrome), the most popular mobile operating system (Android), and the top mapping operation.

However, the DoJ's suit - the biggest against a tech company since it filed an anti-monopoly case against Microsoft in 1998 - is likely to focus on Google's dominance of search, and the ads that it powers.

The case is part of a sweeping crackdown on tech giants, including Apple and Facebook, which rivals and regulators claim use their immense power to tilt the market in their favour, suffocate competitors, distort society and limit free speech.

In addition to the impending action, William Barr, the US attorney general, last week sent a draft law to Congress that would shrink an immunity shield that frees social media giants such as Facebook and YouTube of liability for content posted by users. That legal protection, known as Section 230, is shaping up to be a key battleground for Donald Trump's administration, which claims the tech behemoths censor conservative voices.

A group of Republican senators has called for a vote this week on whether to subpoena the bosses of Alphabet, Facebook and Twitter for a hearing on Section 230. Trump met Republican state attorneys general to discuss the issue.

The pressure is coming from customers and rivals as well. Barry Diller, the billionaire head of IAC, a tech holding firm that includes Expedia and dating app Match, last week dubbed Google an "absolute monopoly". He told The Washington Post that Expedia spent up to $5bn (£3.9bn) a year on ads with Google, but since the search giant started to build its travel business, Expedia's ads received less prominent placement.

"Google is essentially competing with our services while taking our money," Diller said. "I've said to most senior leaders at Google, 'We all are serfs in your universe, in your land. But it's wise to treat your serfs well, which I think you are increasingly not doing. Because if you let that go on for too long, the serfs tend to rise up and attack in hordes.' " Google has denied any wrongdoing, claiming its products, which are offered free, benefit consumers and support innovation. But Diller's critique is at the heart of the government's case against Google, and is what legal experts say is a vulnerability also for Apple.

Both companies are gatekeepers through which others must pass to reach billions of customers. Google, for example, handles 90% of all internet searches. The App Store and Google's Play store are the new shop windows. Apple estimated that in 2019, the App Store facilitated more than $500bn in sales.

To operate these marketplaces, the tech giants charge vast sums. However, they also sell their own products through them, and set up the rules to favour their own. Apple's App Store is ground zero. A group of tech firms last week announced the formation of a lobbying organisation, the Coalition for App Fairness. It includes the likes of Spotify, Diller's Match Group, and Epic Games, the maker of popular video game Fortnite that last month sued Apple over its App Store rules.

The group claims the 30% cut Apple takes on any purchase made through the store is unfair, not least because its own services, such as Spotify rival Apple Music or Arcade - a competitor to Epic - are not subject to the fee.

Diller said Apple's 30% tax was "egregious" , calling it a "hostage payment."

Apple brings in an estimated $15bn a year from App Store fees and rules the marketplace with an iron fist, kicking out any developer that falls foul of the rules, such as requiring that all transactions go through Apple's payment system.

Google also takes 30%, and is expected to update its Android guidelines this week to make it harder for companies to avoid paying it. It also agreed last week to pay $310m to settle a lawsuit over how it handled sexual misconduct claims against former executives.

Fierce critic: Barry Diller

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XJT-MDP1-F03R-N4CX-00000-00U.S. Senate Bill to Block American Companies From Storing Data in China: It's About Time2019-11-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:24ZLexisNexisU.S. Senate Bill to Block American Companies From Storing Data in China: It's About TimeDan Harris

Nov 19, 2019( China Law Blog: http://www.chinalawblog.com Delivered by Newstex) On September 30, inChina's New Cybersecurity Program: NO Place to Hide,[1]we wrote on how China's new cybersecurity laws strip foreign companies of any ability to maintain their trade secrets in China: Under the new Chinese system, trade secrets are not permitted. This means U.S. and EU companies operating in China will now need to assume any 'secret' they seek to maintain on a server or network in China will automatically become available to the Chinese government and then to all of their Chinese government controlled competitors in China, including the Chinese military. This includes phone calls, emails, WeChat messages and any other form of electronic communication. Since no company can reasonably assume its trade secrets will remain secret once transmitted into China over a Chinese controlled network, they are at great risk of having their trade secret protections outside China evaporating as well.

The U.S. or EU company may have an enforceable agreement with the Chinese recipient of its confidential information. So trade secrecy is protected with respect to that authorized recipient. But if the secret is easily available to the Chinese government, there is no real trade secret protection. By giving the Chinese government and its cronies full access to its data, the U.S. or EU company may very well be deemed to have illegally exported technology to China and it could face millions of dollars in fines and even prison sentences for some of its officers and directors. There is an inherent conflict between foreign laws mandating a company not transfer its technology and China's laws which effectively mandate that transfer. A week later, in China's New Cybersecurity System: There is NO Place to Hide[2]we wrote about the Chinese government's goal of scooping up all data, both foreign and domestic, and of how once the Chinese government gets your data, it can do pretty much whatever it wants with it, including turning it over to your competitors: When one examines all of these various different programs together, it becomes apparent that the MLPS 2.0 system is the 'hardware' component of a comprehensive data gathering, surveillance and control program. China's plan is to create a system that coverseveryform of network activity in China: Internet, mobile phone, WeChat type social networks, cloud systems, domestic and international email. China's goal isnotto create a commercial system where individual players can participate and make money. It's goals are surveillance and control by the PRC government and the CCP. * * * * This result then leads to the key issue. Confidential information housed on any server located in China is subject to being viewed and copied by China's Ministry of Public Security and that information then becomes open to access by the entire PRC government system. But the PRC government is the shareholder of the State Owned Entities (SOEs) which are the key industries in China. The PRC government also essentially controls the key private companies in China such as Huawei and ZTE and more recently Alibaba and Tencent and many others. SeeChina is sending government officials into companies like Alibaba and Geely[3]andChina to place government officials inside 100 private companies, including Alibaba[4]. The PRC government also either owns or controls China's entire arms industry. Simply put, the data the Ministry of Public Security obtains from foreign companies will be available to the key competitors of foreign businesses, to the Chinese government controlled and private R...ystem, and to the Chinese arms industry and military. In How China's New CyberSecurity Laws Can (Will?) Destroy Your Business[5], we set out how damaging it will be for foreign companies that turn over their data to the Chinese government, beyond even that the Chinese government and its state-owned companies and universities can now freely possess it. We wrote how turning over this data will 'harm foreign businesses far beyond China because it may violate export control laws and effectively eliminate any trade secret protections that formerly attached to the data': The first harm comes from U.S. export control laws that require certain high-tech information not be disclosed to persons who are not U.S. citizens, green card holders or protected individuals without an export license. These export control laws directly conflict with Chinese law requiringfull and totalgovernment access to that information in China because putting information regarding a controlled technology on a server or a computer in China will instantly create significant export control problems for itself. Foreign companies typically put their private information in China on a private server in China so as to isolate that information from the Chinese government. China's new laws make clear that foreign companiesmustturn over this information to the Chinese government and failing to do so can lead to prison time.This conflict will be an enormous problem for US high tech companies with computer servers in China with high tech information on them because their 'willingness' to give this information to the Chinese government (which obviously is not a U.S. citizen or green card holder) will in some instances constitute criminal law violations of U.S. export control laws. The second way China's latest data subversions will be disastrous for many foreign companies is by eviscerating their trade secret protections.To prevail on a trade secret claim in most countries you must be able to prove the following three things: The secret taken qualifies for trade secret protection. The holder of the secrettook reasonable precautions to prevent disclosure of the secret. The secret waswrongfully taken. Number 2 above could prove to be the downfall of foreign companies in China and here is an example of how that could happen. Suppose your Australian company (this is not just a United States issue) has a trade secret regarding cost efficiently producing a particular product. Suppose you make your China subsidiary makes your product in China and you provide the production information to your China subsidiary so it can cost efficiently make that product. Now further suppose one of your employees at your Germany subsidiary quits the company and sells your trade secret to your largest competitor, based in the United States. You then sue your ex-employee in Germany and your largest competitor in the United States for trade secret violations. No doubt, both your ex-employee and your largest competitor will argue that the information they bought/sold was not a trade secret because by your having revealed this information to the Chinese Government (and to its SOEs and Universities, etc.) means you did not take reasonable precautions to prevent disclosure of the information and therefore the information lost any standing it might have had as a trade secret and your case should be dismissed. Will your ex-employee and your largest competitor win on this argument? Who knows at this point, but I think they will because companies that go into China do so voluntarily and they know that by doing so they are making their information freely available to others. And then pretty much every single day (including yesterday) our China lawyers and/or our data privacy lawyers and/or our international trade lawyers would talk among ourselves about how few foreign companies were grasping the dire repercussions of China's new data laws and of how even the U.S. Government seemed mostly asleep regarding these key issues. Some tech media were covering China's new data laws (Techdirt[6],Cyberwire[7], andBoing Boing[8], for instance) but it was not getting the media attention it deserved. More importantly, we wondered why the United States government had remained mostly silent and we speculated it was because it wanted to lock down Phase One of a trade deal first. But then, on November 7, at the 2019 Web Summit in Lisbon, Michael Kratsios[9], the United States' new Chief Technology Officer, gave a speech indicating he is fully aware of what China has done to secure access to foreign company data: By implementing a dystopian credit score . . . . [and by] extending its authoritarianism abroad, and in no case, is this more clear than with Huawei Chinese law compels all Chinese companies, including Huawei to cooperate with its Intelligence and Security Services, no matter where the company operates in perhaps the most disturbing account of espionage news outlets have reported after Huawei installed communications technology equipment at the headquarters of the African Union, their computer system was hacked and data was transferred to servers in Shanghai, every single night for five years. * * * * [A]nd now they require access to all data, information and secrets contained on any server in China. I strongly urge everyone to read Kratsios entire speech here[10]. Then the just released 2019 U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission Report to Congress[11], cites China Law Blog five times for various propositions (See footnotes 30, 44, 172, 176, 177), including the following While the [new foreign investment] law consolidates previously disparate foreign investment regulations and effectively simplifies China's foreign investment regime, its purported protections for foreign-invested firms may prove unenforceable or be selectively enforced absent more substantive changes that promote genuine rule of law in China's legal system. In other words, foreign companies will not be immune from China's new laws, including its data security laws. But U.S. government silence on China's new data security laws officially ended on November 5 when 'FBI Director Christopher Wray and other intelligence officials testified before the Senate Homeland Security Committee at a hearing on security threats facing the U.S.' Go here[12] to see that testimony on C-SPAN. Then yesterday, Missouri Senator Josh Hawley introduced the 'National Security and Personal Data Protection Act of 2019[13]' to 'Address National Security Concerns Raised by Big Tech's Partnerships with Beijing.[14]' The politically savvy lawyers at my firm (of which I most emphatically do not count myself) insist that the timing of this proposed Act is no coincidence. They say the introduction of this new Act had been put on hold to allow the Phase One trade deal to be signed, but with the New York Times' release of the Xianxjang Papers[15] (a/k/a the 'No Mercy' papers) that deal has now been 'blown up' [16]anyway. Hawley has this[17] to say about his proposed Act: And it's not just Chinese companies that create this risk. Chinese law allows the Communist Party to seize data from American companies operating in China whenever it wants, for whatever reason it wants. This legislation takes crucial steps to stop Americans' sensitive data from falling into the hands of hostile foreign governments. As FBI Director Christopher Wraytestified[18], Chinese law 'compels U.S. companies that are operating in China . . . to provide whatever information the government wants whenever it wants.' This law means that when American companies store encryption keys in China, China can read the messages those keys protect. Senator Hawley's bill prohibits American companies from transferring user data or encryption keys to China and other countries that similarly threaten America's national security. Senator Hawley's bill prohibits American companies fromstoring data in China and other countries that similarly threaten America's national security. Senator Hawley's bill also will greatly limit what Chinese companies can do in the United States, but we will save the analysis on that portion of it for another day. What's most relevant here and now is that it will prohibit American companies from transferring user data or encryption keys to China. But seeing as how when the Chinese police demand such a data transfer from an American company in China, those companies must either comply or go to a Chinese jail for a long time, Hawley's bill prohibits American companies from storing data in China in the first place. If this Act becomes U.S. law, it will have earth-shattering ramifications for American companies that do business in China and I predict some form of this Act will become law. But even if it doesn't, the cat is essentially out of the bag in terms of China's far-reaching and incredibly intrusive laws to get at foreign company data. This proposed Act will jump-start American (and European companies) learning of how their data is at extreme and essentially unmitigated risk in China and of how they need to act accordingly. In our next post, we will explain what 'act accordingly' should look like. As we have been saying since October 6 of last year,[19] welcome to the New Normal. urn:contentItem:60YW-6K01-F11P-X2DY-00000-00US Senate committee subpoenas tech executives2020-10-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:24ZLexisNexisUS Senate committee subpoenas tech executivesMichael Hernandez |

WASHINGTON

The Senate Commerce Committee voted Thursday to subpoena top executives from Facebook, Google and Twitter.

CEOs Mark Zuckerberg, Sundar Pichai and Jack Dorsey will now testify regarding the tech industry's liability shield, Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act (CDA), after senators approved the subpoenas in voice votes.

Voice votes allow for senators to vote orally en masse either in favor or opposition to a measure.

After initially opposing the subpoenas proposed by Chairman Roger Wicker, the committee's top-ranking Democrat, Senator Maria Cantwell, backed the measure. She said, however, "what I don't want to see is a chilling effect on individuals who are in a process of trying to crack down on hate speech, or misinformation about COVID during a pandemic."

"I welcome the debate about 230," she said. "I think it should be a long and thoughtful process. Not sure that a long and thoughtful process will happen before the election, but I understand my colleagues' desires here today."

US President Donald Trump and his Republican allies have sought to focus on Section 230 in their criticism of what they say are efforts among social media companies to censor conservative viewpoints.

The president in May issued an executive order calling for new regulations to be imposed on the legal protections, which are part of a largely defunct 1996 law that has been used to protect internet companies from lawsuits.

Walker, the committee chairman, charged big tech companies with determining "what millions of Americans read, view and hear every day."

"Over time this law has undeniably allowed the modern internet to flourish. It has helped usher in more speech and more expression, and limited the proliferation of truly reprehensible content," he said.

"However, following repeated and consistent reports of political bias and the suppression of certain viewpoints, I fear that Section 230's sweeping liability protections for big tech are stifling a true diversity of political discourse on the internet," he added.

Section 230 is one of the few remaining parts of the CDA, which was largely struck down by the Supreme Court over free speech concerns.

The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) digital rights group calls the section "the most important law protecting internet speech."

It protects not only Internet Service Providers but also websites that publish information from third parties, like Twitter and Facebook, from being held legally responsible for what others post on their platforms.

"This legal and policy framework has allowed for YouTube and Vimeo users to upload their own videos, Amazon and Yelp to offer countless user reviews, craigslist to host classified ads, and Facebook and Twitter to offer social networking to hundreds of millions of Internet users," the EFF said, describing its far-reaching applications.

It also has allowed blog websites to host comment sections and not be held liable for what is posted within.

"In short, CDA 230 is perhaps the most influential law to protect the kind of innovation that has allowed the Internet to thrive since 1996," it added, using an acronym for the law's name.
